definition[0]: to officially allow someone to leave somewhere, especially the hospital or the army, navy etc, or to tell them that they must leave
note[0]: discharge yourself British English (=leave hospital before your treatment is complete)
example[0]: Hospitals now tend to discharge patients earlier than in the past.
example[2]: Dunning was conditionally discharged for two years.
example[3]: Several of the recruits were discharged from the Army due to medical problems.
definition[1]: to send out gas, liquid, smoke etc, or to allow it to escape
example[4]: Sewage is discharged directly into the sea.
example[5]: Rainwater collects here and then discharges into the river Kennett.
definition[2]: to fire a gun or shoot an arrow etc
example[6]: A soldier accidentally discharged his weapon.
definition[3]: to do or pay what you have a duty to do or pay
example[7]: The trustees failed to discharge their duties properly.
definition[4]: if a piece of electrical equipment discharges, or if it is discharged, it sends out electricity
definition[5]: if a wound or body part discharges a substance such as pus (=infected liquid), the substance slowly comes out of it
definition[6]: to take goods or passengers off a ship, plane etc
definition[7]: when you officially allow someone to leave somewhere, especially the hospital or their job in the army, navy etc
example[8]: Nurses visit the mother and baby for two weeks after their discharge from the hospital.
definition[8]: when gas, liquid, smoke etc is sent out, or the substance that is sent out
example[9]: the discharge of toxic waste into the sea
definition[9]: when a substance slowly comes out of a wound or part of your body, or the substance that comes out
definition[10]: electricity that is sent out by a piece of equipment, a storm etc
definition[11]: when someone performs a duty or pays a debt
example[10]: the discharge of the college’s legal responsibilities
definition[13]: to officially allow or tell someone to leave hospital, the army, a job etc
example[11]: The men were treated for minor injuries and discharged.
example[12]: He was discharged from the RAF last August.
definition[14]: to remove someone from their job
example[13]: In December, the airline discharged 49 employees and said it might need to make further cuts.
definition[15]: to do properly everything that is part of a particular duty etc
example[14]: The committee said that the Bank had failed to discharge its supervisory duties.
definition[16]: to completely pay an amount that is owed
example[15]: The payment of £4,000 together with the monthly sum of £1,000 was not enough to discharge in full the invoice for January’s work.
definition[17]: to send out gas, liquid, smoke etc, or allow it to escape
example[16]: Gas leaked from the tanker as it discharged crude oil at the refinery.
example[17]: pollutants being discharged into the atmosphere
definition[18]: to take goods off a ship, plane etc
example[18]: The ship discharged the 2,911-tonne cargo of 330 concrete-coated steel pipes in less than a day.
definition[19]: to state officially that someone who was bankrupt has obeyed the court and can do business again
definition[20]: when someone is officially allowed or told to leave hospital, the army, a job etc
example[19]: The organization helps ex-servicemen and their dependants following discharge from the forces.
definition[21]: when someone is removed from their job
example[20]: He threatened to sue the firm for wrongful discharge.
definition[22]: when someone performs a duty, responsibility etc properly and thoroughly
example[21]: Although we do not consider Mr Gray’s conduct to have been dishonest, the discharge of his responsibilities as company secretary was most unsatisfactory.
definition[23]: when an amount such as a debt or money claimed on an insurance policy is completely paid
example[22]: the residue of the estate after the discharge of all debts and liabilities
definition[24]: when gas, liquid, smoke etc is sent out or allowed to escape
example[23]: £1 billion has been spent to control sewage discharges.
definition[25]: when goods are taken off a ship, plane etc
example[24]: Checking the discharge of cargo is part of my job.
